title: A Cloud Solution for Personalized Object Recognition
description: A cloud system that enables blind and visually-impaired people to teach and recognize personal objects

content.value: Imagine you were blind and wanted to find your personal items. Today's technology in computer vision offers a variety of solutions, from human assistance apps like Be My Eyes to AI with vision capabilities like GP4-vision to help recognize objects. Let's say you might use these AI apps to find your ID card, only for it to say, 'a blue card with text on it,' and you have to guess which one it is.

Our cloud solution bridges this gap by allowing blind and visually-impaired users to teach the AI to recognize their personal items accurately. Unlike general object recognition models, our system learns the unique features of each item, providing precise and meaningful descriptions. This enables users to confidently identify their belongings without second-guessing.

content.description: Users can teach their personal belongings to the system
Users can input what they want to find for the system to check with matched image vector from the database

content.value: The project leverages vector search techniques to store and retrieve image dat from personal items. By using CLIP model to extract zero-shot image embeddings, the system can extract features and can be taught to recognize items matter most to users. This not only enhances accessibility but also empowers users to be more independent in their daily lives.

Our innovative approach earned us a spot in the final round of Microsoft Thailand's AI for Accessibility Hackathon 2024. This recognition underscores the impact and potential of our solution to transform the lives of those with visual impairments.

title: Daily Brainy: A Fully-automated Neuroscience Content Creator
description: I developed an automated system that edits and posts short videos about neuroscience daily on YouTube and Instagram

content.value: Large language models are flourishing in the open, but most are still built in silos. Communities can form around a model, but their contributions can take months or years to be merged back to the base model — if they make their way back at all.
“There’s no good way to combine all of that innovation into a coherent whole,” said David Cox, vice president for AI models at IBM Research.

InstructLab, an open-source project launched by IBM and Red Hat in May, is designed to change that. It gives communities the tools to create and merge changes to LLMs without having to retrain the model from scratch. By making LLMs more like any other open-source software project, IBM and Red Hat hope to democratize access to generative AI.
